comments.value:
The Current Kitsite VMs that host the London2012 website are running on unpatched RHEL 5.1.

Under guidance from BT we are looking to upgrade these servers to Redhat 5.6 and apply the full set of YUM security patches.

We are looking to do this in staging first - updating Stage03 and 04 and fully testing before moving to the web servers.  When we upgrade the web servers we will be taking each server out of the load balancer, making the changes, testing the box and returning it to the load balanced pool.

We will need Kitsite help and assistance with this to indentify a suitable window for this work to take place, and to be on had in case there are any issues with the patching.

A Redhat upgrade shouldn't affect the web servers, but it would be a good idea to do stage04 first and ensure that it can be accessed directly via port 80/443 so that it can be tested in isolation.

Any problems with stage03 might impact publishing to the live environment, so cannot be recommended without extensive testing first.

Danny - agree that we should do this in that order.

The date that we have for doing this now is Weds 19th October for the staging and Thurs/fri for the production servers.  Hope this date works for you guys.

Russ

Wed 19th is good for staging, although please not my earlier comment: "it would be a good idea to do stage04 first and ensure that it can be accessed directly via port 80/443 so that it can be tested in isolation."

Stage04 cannot as far I know be accessed directly at present, so you may want to raise a CR adding a new sub-domain, stage04.london2012.com, with access from within your network and our IP addresses (which you should already have on file).

We would not recommend applying any patches on Friday, for the usual reasons.

hi danny - we have set up a new subdomain for communicating directly with stage04 - access from Kitiste and Locog.

pickle.london2012.com  can you set up the hostfile to point this at stage04 for us.

Also it is also looking likely that we will not be doing this on the 19th as the eDNS change has slipped which means that we are needing to focus on eDNS next week
We have changed httpd.com on staging and pickle.london2012.com now points to http://pickle.london2012.com/
Or possibly not. Russ, I will get back to you on this one tomorrow.

Hi Sharique,

I can confirm that there were no changes made to the docroot for the festival site during this period. Fyi, I did this as follows:
  find /apps/apache/html/festival.london2012.com -mtime -2

Do you know the nature of the Akamai error message? Does it indicate that the origin server was unreachable? or reachable, but no http connection possible, or perhaps that the apache server was reachable, but returning an http error code?

Have you consulted the Apache logs pertaining to this period? I'm happy to do so, but don't want to duplicate what you may be doing.

Kind regards,
Kieran

Hi Kieran,
We have already raise ticket with BT and they are investigating Akamai logs, we had experience this problem previously as well and previously it was Akamai who could not get any response from source, that’s why I thought to mail you in advance in case if there was any change made, I will let you know we need any further information from Kitsite.

Thanks for your help.

Regards
Sharique

Hi Kieran,
This is what we get from BT and it looks like some files are missing on server, can you investigate this please,

Have looked back through previous ticket for this incident INC0094108

The Akamai errors are repeatedly as follows:

19/Aug/11 08:32:52 217.156.169.206 GET /D/336/129605/000/origin-festival.london2012.com/ 0 0 5000 - - - 213.120.228.200 -

Result is a 504 back to the end-user.

During the outage IPSoft looked at their device which is hosting the website and got the following:

[Fri Aug 19 11:03:40 2011] [error] [client 80.239.228.12] File does not exist: /apps/apache/html/festival.london2012.com/images/presentation
[Fri Aug 19 11:03:40 2011] [error] [client 80.239.228.12] script '/apps/apache/html/festival.london2012.com/error-404.php' not found or unable to stat [Fri Aug 19 11:05:15 2011] [error] [client 62.41.62.62] File does not exist: /apps/apache/html/festival.london2012.com/images/presentation
[Fri Aug 19 11:05:15 2011] [error] [client 62.41.62.62] script '/apps/apache/html/festival.london2012.com/error-404.php' not found or unable to stat [Fri Aug 19 11:06:11 2011] [error] [client 80.239.228.12] File does not exist: /apps/apache/html/festival.london2012.com/images/presentation
[Fri Aug 19 11:06:11 2011] [error] [client 80.239.228.12] script '/apps/apache/html/festival.london2012.com/error-404.php' not found or unable to stat [Fri Aug 19 11:08:15 2011] [error] [client 80.239.228.12] File does not exist: /apps/apache/html/festival.london2012.com/images/presentation
[Fri Aug 19 11:08:15 2011] [error] [client 80.239.228.12] script '/apps/apache/html/festival.london2012.com/error-404.php' not found or unable to stat

It is as if the server is unable to access the required files form the aplication in the /apps/apache/html/festival.london2012.com/ directory.

As IPSoft have previously stated, if this is just one website affected then it can not be the infrastructure as this hosts multiple websites.

BAU Internet, Pelase investgiate this further with the developers.


Thanks
Sharique

Hi Sharique,
Those error messages are from 19 Aug (and I believe - altho I don't have it immediately to hand - dealt with in another ticket).
This ticket is - afaik - regarding an suspected outage on 4 Sep?
Kieran

Hi Tom,

I think these are already in these pages?

Also the 'email confirmation' page (https://www.london2012.com/settings/registration-confirmation.php) this is a global page used for loads of other purposes (it's not limited to travel users).

Secondly these pages are based on templates and so we'll need to add the tags to the templates (not the pages), this means we'll have to add in hard coded rules about which tags to display depending on the url / path / filename and if the pages get renamed or moved for any reason then the tags will break. In this case that is unlikely to happen (I think that section is fairly set in stone) but in other cases it may be an issue.

In terms of the links, I think we added these in as well? If not all those links are editable in the CMS so you can just add them in (although as they all have adfarm.mediplex.com urls they will be seen by the CMS as external pages and hence may get 'external link' icons - this is done deep down in the publication layer and isn't easy to change).

Happy to have a chat, although tomorrow would be better than today.

btw. can you not share your stat data from Google Analytics with TFL rather than us adding yet another set of ad tracking tags to the templates/pages?

Jamie

This looks like an issue for Akamai. It's their certificate and the site is being served through their network. We have no control over this.
But should we not be ensuring that the sign-up elements are delivered via https://? They are not currently.

Hi Morag,

We don't / can't install the certificates on Akamai, that's something Technology will have to get Akamai to do.

Although, they are correct the web01-06 is not setup to deliver pages over SSL for festival.london2102.com as weren't made aware this was a requirement, neither do we have a certificate to use for festival.london2102.com 

If it has now become a requirement I think these are the rough step that need to happen:

btw. I am not entirely sure who last installed the www.london2102.com certificate and/or if we are allowed to install them [am trying to find Kieran to ask if he remembers]. Assuming for the moment we can generate the CSR / install the cert for you.

1/ Kitsite (or ipsoft) need to generate a CSR (certificate signing request) for festival.london2012.com
2/ LOCOG need to order a SSL certificate using that CSR (for use on web01-06)
3/ Kitsite (or ipsoft) need to instal the certificates on web01-06
4/ Kitsite (or ipsoft) need to update the Apache httpd.conf on web01-06
5/ Kitsite need to add a rule to each Apache httpd.conf to redirect form traffic to https and non-form traffic back to http
6/ Kitsite (or ipsoft) need to restart all web servers
7/ Kitsite need to update the HTML/JS to link to a https version of the signup form and the accessible version of the form [need to work out scope of those changes as the form is submitted via AJAX]
8/ We also need to check that every other asset (image, js, css etc.) on the page can also be loaded via https to get round mixed content warnings, as the site is effectively one large JS app this could be a non trivial process (hard to tell without some investigation).

ps. one thing to be aware of (before we embark on what is a non trivial amount of work) is that the form itself is served up empty (there is no personal data in an empty form) so there little advantage from a security perspective to serving an empty form that up as a https page (other than a padlock appearing). The only thing that *really* need to be made secure is the transmission of data from the form to the CMS once it is posted off. 

## I know you have very strict data protection requirements, but I would personally question how personal this data actually is? Is someone really going to sniff a network to capture someone email address? I just did a straw poll, but most (large) site capturing this data don't do it over HTTPS ie. the weekly newsletter signup form on TimeOut http://www.timeout.com/london/ ##

Kieran's not in today, but he's in the London office next week, we'll do out best to get back to you on Monday/Tuesday with a more confirmed list of tasks and timescales, with a provisional schedule to carry out the work (assuming you want us to press ahead with it).

Jamie

Thanks, Jamie – very very helpful.

Will relay to Technology and get them to make a call.

Ticket #4721 "Festival Website" was closed and merged into this ticket.

Last comment in ticket #4721: This is a follow up to #4601.

Hi Danny

This one will not go away I am afraid.

Can we speak about how best to do this – understand Jamie’s concerns but our security folks have strict policies on the transmission of personal data.

As this is on Akamai can we not just put the whole thing on the Akamai secure network and use their wildcard *.london2012 certificate?

Russ

Hi Russ,

Given you now host the wildcard *.london2012 certificate cert with Akamai then yes, as you suggest, we could just serve the entire site over https.

Given that the site is basically a one page AJAX / JS driven site that probably isn't such a crazy idea (we probably need to revisit for festival phase II though)

Someone (not sure who manages the conf files in stage03/04 and web01/06 now) would just need to add a Apache rule to rewrite all http request back to a https alternative.

We'd also need to make sure that all the urls in the pages that reference assets do so via https urls so we don't get any mixed content warnings, this will still need some preliminary work (to check and migrate over any references) which we will need to schedule in.

One last thing, do we still need a SSL certificate installed on the server (even if just a self signed one) in order to ensure that the connection between the origin server and Akamai is over a secure transport or is the whole network inside of Akamai considered secure (even if those connections are only over http). I seem to remember Dom saying that the origin server did need a cert installed even if just a self signed one). If this is the case then we'd need to figure out who is to complete this work IPSoft or ourselves. This would need installing on stage03/04 and web01-06. 

Although I do wonder, in light of everything now sitting behind Akamai whether it would make sense to install a self signed wildcard cert (no reason for a proper one as no one will see it) on stage03/04 and web01-06 so that those servers are setup to handle any sub sites under the london2012.com domain.

Probably best Danny if you liaise with Russ on this / schedule any work in.

thanks

Jamie

Thanks Jamie – did not mean to go direct to Danny on this when you had given such a comprehensive answer.

Russ

Hi Russ,

No, I just meant could Danny (who was cc'd in) pick this ticket back up to figure out a schedule / thrash out the details with you for getting this work done.

Not that Danny is my PA ;-) It's just that he has a better overall picture of our availability and probably has more time than me this week to discuss the finer details with yourself and Akamai.

thanks

Jamie

Russ, regarding Jamie's list of tasks added in July:

1/ Kitsite (or ipsoft) need to generate a CSR (certificate signing request) for festival.london2012.com 
2/ LOCOG need to order a SSL certificate using that CSR (for use on web01-06) 
3/ Kitsite (or ipsoft) need to instal the certificates on web01-06 
4/ Kitsite (or ipsoft) need to update the Apache httpd.conf on web01-06 
5/ Kitsite need to add a rule to each Apache httpd.conf to redirect form traffic to https and non-form traffic back to http 
6/ Kitsite (or ipsoft) need to restart all web servers 
7/ Kitsite need to update the HTML/JS to link to a https version of the signup form and the accessible version of the form [need to work out scope of those changes as the form is submitted via AJAX] 
8/ We also need to check that every other asset (image, js, css etc.) on the page can also be loaded via https to get round mixed content warnings, as the site is effectively one large JS app this could be a non trivial process (hard to tell without some investigation).

I can confirm that this is where responsibility lies:

1/ ipsoft need to generate a CSR (certificate signing request) for festival.london2012.com 
2/ LOCOG need to order a SSL certificate using that CSR (for use on web01-06) 
3/ ipsoft need to instal the certificates on web01-06 
4/ Kitsite need to update the Apache httpd.conf on web01-06 
5/ Kitsite need to add a rule to each Apache httpd.conf to redirect form traffic to https and non-form traffic back to http 
6/ ipsoft need to restart all web servers
7/ Kitsite need to update the HTML/JS to link to a https version of the signup form and the accessible version of the form [need to work out scope of those changes as the form is submitted via AJAX] 
8/ We also need to check that every other asset (image, js, css etc.) on the page can also be loaded via https to get round mixed content warnings, as the site is effectively one large JS app this could be a non trivial process (hard to tell without some investigation).

So, if you are able to liaise with IPsoft, BT and Akamai to get the certificate installed we should be able to do the rest.

As a follow up to this one and in particular with regard to items 2/ and 3/, our understanding is that the only way to have:
 - host1.london2012.com
 - host2.london2012.com
both listening on https/443

is to have a wildcard cert, for *.london2012.com

(because apache needs to know which cert to use BEFORE it inspects the virtual hosts and it doesn't know the hostname until it decrypts the request)

So it looks like somebody will need to set that up before we can proceed.
Incidentally, fwiw, the current cert is NOT a wildcard *.london2012.com cert (see attached - it's just for www.london2012.com).

Add audio files (mp3) and an interactive map?

One of the themes on the site will be archaeology and this section will be slightly different, with a few more pages. It would be great to know if we would have the capabilities of audio and using an interactive map.

Andy, can you give some examples on facebook with URLs of posts that are displaying this problem?

No, as we’ve not posted anything in the last few days. But you can try yourself just by going to any page on the website and using the share on Facebook link at the bottom, or pasting the URL directly into Facebook.

The one I found it with was:
http://www.london2012.com/games/torch-relays/index.php

As far as I can tell if affects most pages but not the home page. These randomly selected ones don’t work:
http://www.london2012.com/making-it-happen/sustainability/index.php

That said, I’ve just found that this one does:
http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/upcoming-events/index.php

Curious.

It appears that the Facebook share interface is now deprecated in favour of their 'Like" button: http://developers.facebook.com/docs/reference/plugins/like/

The upshot is that behaviour of http://www.facebook.com/sharer.php cannot be guaranteed and there appears to be no way of forcing page images to load.

We may want to consider changing our page links to use the new interface.

I think this is one for Finn to drive, but yes, I believe we will need to update the share interface.

The article here is interesting and suggests a few things to try:
http://ansonalex.com/troubleshooting/fix-articles-linked-on-facebook-dont-display-thumbnails-images/

Also, I’ve noticed that the Facebook lint checker fails to find images on most of our pages – in particular (for the pages I’ve tried) shop product images and supporter logos in PNG format.

Finn – what priority is this for you?
It certainly would be nice to get this working properly. I guess it depends on how much work this is for you Danny. I’d like you to find that out please though so we can make a call on it.

Probably the correct way to solve this issue is to use Facebook's Open Graph Protocol: http://developers.facebook.com/docs/opengraph/ 

This would not mean changing the facebook code at all, but it would mean adding code to the header of the page.

We could probably add a single "<meta property="og:image" content="http://www.london2012.com/some-image.jpg"/>" to the top of all pages. 

Alternatively, we could probably allow the content of this tag to be specified page by page, but this would add an extra layer of editorial effort and require a bit of coding.

The simplest approach would be a single new metatag to be added to all pages which could possibly be done in under a day (almost all of which would be confirming this approach will work, testing and deployment, rather than actual development).

Other approaches would take more time, depending on what we actually ended up doing.

comments.value:
We are looking at how we can easily isolate parts of our site from the basic London2012 site in case of issues.  For example, if the shop went down or was corrupted we would want to put a page up instead of linking to shop.london2012.com to isolate it.  There are a number of areas that we would want to do this to:

Getset
Tickets
Shop
Pregames training camps
Recruitment
Mascots
Estimate and timescale needed.

Two options (at least): == Option one We could wrap all external links in a piece of (pseudo) php: if (SHOP_DISABLED) { // output nothing } else { Shop } "SHOP_DISABLED" would be a global php variable that can be set in response to reports of problems with the shop. Pros: shop.london2012.com would receive correct HTTP_REFERER info. Cons: Need to login to staging server, or amend a php file in the cms in order to set this variable (and hence disable shop links). In either case, it's simple, but potentially dangerous. == Option two We could host "interim" pages for each external url. i.e. the links would look as follows: Shop This page would then serve a redirect to http://shop.london2012.com. If we need to decouple the shop for some reason, then we simply amend the /interim-shop-page.php page, and republish. Pros: The interim page can be configured to show a message (e.g. "the shop is currently unavailable, sorry") during downtime periods. Cons: The shop would /not/ receive correct HTTPP_REFERER info. We can discuss other options, if neither of the above is acceptable. Both of them involve scouring the template code for hard-coded links to external urls, and so could prove quite time-consuming. I'm estimating 5 days here (for everything - technical solution, template amendments, testing, deployment) but it might be higher, depending on the solution we choose.

Russ says that the priority is for it to be easy to make changes, so that locog staff can update the links without our assistance, similar to the existing get-involved/volunteer/atos-returning-user-redirect.php. So, Option two is the preferred route.

Ok, well ... I estimate 5 days.
Can I just (double) confirm that everyone is ok with the referrer data being lost?
By this, I mean that (for example) /all/ hits on shop.london2012.com will appear to have come from "http://www.london2012.com/redirect/shop.php". Thus meaning that shop.london2012.com cannot do any analytics on which www.london2012.com pages generate them the most traffic.

There is one possible alternative, but it would have to be okayed by the SEO people first:
Lets say "http://www.london2012.com/some-page.php" wants to link to "http://shop.london2012.com/".
Instead of using a dedicated proxy page, we could - instead - link to itself, but with a querystring param added:
  http://www.london2012.com/some-page.php?redir=shop
This page would then notice the "redir=shop" and serve a 302 (or 303?) to send the user to: http://shop.london2012.com/. The shop would thus still see the referrer info which - I presume - is of some commercial value to you and them.

To do it this way would probably add another day to the task - although it /might/ still come in at 5 days.

Kieran

I agree – need to be sure that we don’t foul up the analytics on this – good catch.

Russ

Have set this to pending.
If authorized, I will set it back to "Open" and complete the work.
just spoke to Russ about this, too. He said he will get back to us later in the month.

This is a horrible timesink. Page editor is close to unacceptable in IE, especially when trying to deal with rich elements. It has quite a few browser hacks (instead of feature hacks), but I'm afraid it never worked perfectly on IE. I'd advise to use IE for just very basic text editing stuff and fall back for firefox for anything like this. The long term solution would be to cut down page editor features to half and code that reliably and/or have strict browser requirements.

Zara, we have spent quite a bit of time investigated this issue and the prognosis is not terribly good.

Internet Explorer has always been somewhat problematic for dealing with rich text editing. While it is fine for doing simple editing tasks, some things just do not work as well as we would like in IE. 

Getting picture deletion and uploading working properly in IE is likely to require a considerable amount of developer effort.

Our best advise (and I realise that this is suboptimal for you), is to fall back to Firefox for anything but the more simple editing tasks. If it is possible, we strongly recommend installing Firefox onto your PC.

Hi Danny

Thanks for this. I have Firefox and cvan work in that, but going forward when we have a bigger team and volunteers, they won't all have f/fox and that could cause issues at gametime. Could I get a quote/ timescale of how long it would take to fix this in IE?

Thanks, Zara
Jamie, over to you for this. I am assuming she doesn't actually mean games time itself. Or maybe she is not aware that delta tre are taking over before the games.

Given how tricky this will be to fix, it may actually make more sense to look at changing the templates where Zara is trying to assign images and seeing if we can use a <content:picture> container instead.

In short the inline images/editing stuff only has so much mileage and we could just be on a fruitless struggle trying to resolve it (the real answer is probably to re-write the page editor / rich text editor from the ground up, but as that isn't realistically going to happen this year, putting a time against this ticket to do that is rather pointless. In theory if we could get Michael in for a months he possible could rewrite it, but then I expect we'd end up with another two dozen new issues as a result of doing that).

Looking at the templates and how we could restructure them so we could use a <content:picture> container is however realistic, although a bit open ended / more a design issue.

Zara, apologies for taking so long to get back to you on this one, but this is a somewhat intractable problem, without a realistic timescale. 

However, there is another solution which we haven't mentioned: refactoring the page template so that instead of inline images, we place image containers in specific locations on the page. This may even be a better solution than allowing inline images if you are likely to have more people entering content over the next 12 months, because it enforces layout more than adding images inline on an ad hoc basis.

So, to summarize, the options are:

1. Use Firefox;

2. Refactor templates so that there are more pre-defined slots for image containers.
Zara, we have spent 2+ days on this over the last several months (mostly back in December/January). I am going to mark this as solved with one billable day on it, if that is OK with you.
